header.title: Introduction

chapter.p: The Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) development toolkit contains the following parts:

item.p: An extensible multilingual SNMP agent, which understands SNMPv1, SNMPv2c, SNMPv3, or any combination of these protocols
A multilingual SNMP manager
A MIB compiler, which understands SMIv1 and SMIv2

chapter.p: The SNMP development tool provides an environment for rapid agent/manager prototyping and construction. With the following information provided, this tool is used to set up a running multilingual SNMP agent/manager:

item.p: A description of a Management Information Base (MIB) in Abstract Syntax Notation One (ASN.1)
Instrumentation functions for the managed objects in the MIB, written in Erlang

chapter.p: The advantage of using an extensible (agent/manager) toolkit is to remove details such as type checking, access rights, Protocol Data Unit (PDU), encoding, decoding, and trap distribution from the programmer, who only has to write the instrumentation functions that implement the MIBs. The get-next function only has to be implemented for tables, and not for every variable in the global naming tree. This information can be deduced from the ASN.1 file.

section.title: Scope and Purpose
section.p: This manual describes the SNMP development tool as a component of the Erlang/OTP development environment.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: It is assumed that the reader is familiar with the following:

list.item: Basics of the community-based SNMP version 2 (SNMPv2c)
How to define MIBs using SMIv1 and SMIv2
The Erlang Development Environment, which is described in a separate User's Guide

section.p: The tool requires Erlang release 4.7 or later.

section.title: Terms
section.p: The following terms are used in this User's Guide:

taglist.item: The conceptual repository for management information is called the Management Information Base (MIB). It does not hold any data, merely a definition of what data can be accessed. A definition of a MIB is a description of a collection of managed objects.
The MIB is specified in an adapted subset of the Abstract Syntax Notation One (ASN.1) language. This adapted subset is called the Structure of Management Information (SMI).
ASN.1 is used in two different ways in SNMP. The SMI is based on ASN.1 and the messages in the protocol are defined by using ASN.1.

item.p: A resource to be managed is represented by a managed object, which resides in the MIB. In an SNMP MIB, the managed objects are one of the following:

list.item: Scalar variables, which have only one instance per context; they have single values, not multiple values like vectors or structures
A table element, which is a special type of scalar variable

taglist.item: SNMP relies on the three basic operations: get (object), set (object, value), and get-next (object).
An instrumentation function is associated with each managed object. This function implements the operations and is called by the agent when it receives a request from the management station.
A manager generates commands and receives notifications from agents. Usually only a few managers exist in a system.
An agent responds to commands from the manager, and sends notifications to it. There are potentially many agents in a system.

section.title: About This Manual
section.p: This User's Guide is organized as follows:

item.p: Section 1, "Introduction" (this section).
Section 2, "Agent Functional Description", describes the features and operation of the SNMP development toolkit. It includes topics on subagents, MIB loading, internal MIBs, and traps.
Section 3, "Manager Functional Description", describes the manager.
Section 4, "The MIB Compiler", describes the features and the operation of the MIB compiler.
Section 5, "Running the Application", describes how to start and configure the application. Topics on how to debug the application are also included.
Section 6, "Definition of Agent Configuration Files", is a reference section, which contains details about the agent configuration files.
Section 7, "Definition of Manager Configuration Files", is a reference section, which contains details about the manager configuration files.
Section 8, "Agent Implementation Example", describes how a MIB can be implemented with the SNMP development toolkit. Implementation examples are also included.
Section 9, "Manager Implementation Example", describes how a simple manager can be implemented with the SNMP development toolkit.
Section 10, "Instrumentation Functions", describes how to define instrumentation functions in Erlang for the different operations.
Section 11, "Definition of Instrumentation Functions", is a reference section, which contains details about the instrumentation functions.
Section 12, "Definition of Agent Net if" is a reference section, which describes the Agent Net if function in detail.
Section 13, "Definition of Manager Net if" is a reference section, which describes the Manager Net if function in detail.
Section 14, "Audit Trail Log", descibes the audit trail logging.
Section 15, "Advanced Agent Topics", describes subagents, agent semantics, audit trail logging, and the consideration of distributed tables.
"SNMP Appendix A" describes the conversion of SNMPv2 to SNMPv1 error messages.
"SNMP Appendix B" contains the RFC 1903 text on RowStatus.

section.title: Where to Find More Information
section.p: For more information about SNMP and the Erlang/OTP development system:

list.item: Marshall T. Rose (1991), "The Simple Book - An Introduction to Internet Management", Prentice-Hall
Evan McGinnis and David Perkins (1997), "Understanding SNMP MIBs", Prentice-Hall
Concurrent Programming in Erlang, 2nd Edition (1996), Prentice-Hall, ISBN 0-13-508301-X
For SNMPv1: RFC 1155, RFC 1157, RFC 1212, RFC 1213, RFC 1215
For SNMPv2c: RFC 1901, RFC 1902, RFC 1903, RFC 1904, RFC 1905, RFC 1906, RFC 1907
For coexistence between SNMPv1 and SNMPv2: RFC 1908, RFC 2089
For SNMP standard MIBs: RFC 2271, RFC 2273
